data.name: P/E Ratio Basics
data.text: The P/E ratio compares a company's current stock price to its earnings per share (EPS). A low P/E ratio can indicate that a stock is undervalued, while a high P/E ratio can mean that a stock is overvalued. However, it's important to consider other factors when deciding whether to invest in a company based on its P/E ratio.

questions.text: What can a low P/E ratio indicate?
Is P/E ratio the only factor to consider when investing in a company?

data.name: Analyzing P/E Ratios
data.text: When comparing P/E ratios, it's important to compare companies in the same industry. For example, a technology company may have a higher P/E ratio than a utility company due to its potential for faster growth. Additionally, historical P/E ratios can provide insight into a company's stock valuation.

questions.text: Should you compare P/E ratios of companies in different industries?
Why may a technology company have a higher P/E ratio than a utility company?
What can historical P/E ratios provide insight into?
